translated: The Sutra of the Great Buddha and the Great Sangha Spoken by the Buddha
Translated by Layman Juqu Jingsheng of the Song Dynasty
The Buddha was in the country of RÄjagá¹›ha. There was a wealthy man in the country named Li, with countless gold, silver, various treasures, fields, houses, cattle, horses, male and female servants.
Li was old and had no heir.
The constant law of the country was that after a person died without a son, all their property would be confiscated by the government.
Li prayed to the sun, moon, various gods, ghosts, spirits, the Nine Sons' Mother, mountain tree spirits, all requesting a son, but could not obtain one.
Li thought to himself:

When people have urgent matters, they often go to take refuge in the mountain tree spirits, to no avail - wealth and treasures are exhausted, productive work is not done, illnesses come one after another, calamities follow one after another, male and female servants die, livestock do not multiply - all are considered to be evil omens.

The ghost and spirit guides, the confused and dancing servants, disturb the ruler within the inner quarters, saying there will be blessings, but heavy misfortune arrives. It is like a blind person swallowing poison and calling it a good medicine, hoping for some relief, but the poison takes hold and they lose their life.
I now kill living beings and make offerings to ghosts and spirits, and will enter hell, yet hope for the blessings of heaven. Isn't this confusing?
In the world there is the Buddha's Way, the sages of lofty conduct, and those who have attained immortality, called Perfected Men.

The Perfected Men are pure, like lapis lazuli beads. By diligently maintaining concentration, one can only see them. Those who follow this Way only keep to tranquility, without desire or seeking, taking this as joy. In this life they attain peace, and in the end they are born in the heavens.
Li thought to himself:
I will always make offerings and revere the Three Jewels of Buddhism.
After a year of following Buddhism, his wife gave birth to a son. Li said:
By following Buddhism and fulfilling my wishes, I will name him Fuda. The disciples of the Buddha are called bhiká¹£u monks.
He tried serving her again, and before a year had passed, she gave birth to another wise son, named Sengda.
Li taught the two sons, showing them the path of sages.

Sengda inherited a nature of kindness and love for people, with filial piety difficult to match. He recited the Buddhist precepts, befriended Å›ramaá¹‡as, and was content with purity. Seeing his aspirations, his parents loved him especially.
When his parents fell ill and lay in bed, they immediately called their eldest son and wept, admonishing him:

Life has death, all things are impermanent. Those who uphold the precepts are at ease, those who violate the precepts are in danger. Those who uphold the Buddha's precepts have no worries from beginning to end.
Sengda is still young, but he is kind, filial, and pure... Li repeated this several times, and as soon as the words were finished, he suddenly passed away.
His younger brother went to heaven, orphaned and without a place to turn. He repeatedly asked his elder brother:
I want to become a Å›ramaá¹‡a.
The law of their country was that if a son wanted to find a wife, he would pretend to say:
I want to become a Å›ramaá¹‡a.
His relatives feared this might happen, so they arranged a marriage for him.

Buddhadatta then sought out the most virtuous woman in the country, named SupriyÄ, who was radiant, upright, and nearly peerless in beauty. Her height, shortness, plumpness, and thinness were just right, and she was chaste, kind, and filial, like the moon among the stars. No woman or virtuous wife in the country did not sigh with admiration.
When the bride entered the hall, her brother gathered guests, and the nine clans rejoiced, all living in harmony and happiness.
The brother teased his younger brother in front of the guests:
On this day, can you become a Å›ramaá¹‡a?
Sengda replied:
Elder brother!
Allow me to become a Å›ramaá¹‡a, it is truly my long-cherished wish.
The brother, knowing that he truly wanted to do so, joked with him, saying:
You may follow your wish.
The younger brother's heart was filled with joy, he bowed to his brother, and that very day he entered the mountains.
He saw a young and handsome monk sitting alone under a tree. He approached, joined his palms, bowed in respect, and then asked, saying:
Virtuous one, for what reason did you become a monk?
That person had already attained the path of arhatship and could precognitively know the events of countless eons past and future. He said to Sengda:
The Buddha's sutras say:
'If a person indulges in lust like fire burning the body, it is like carrying a torch against the wind.

If the flames gradually recede and one does not put down the torch, the fire will burn one's hand, just like a crow carrying meat chased by hawks and falcons. If the crow does not let go of the meat, disaster will befall its life.
' Lust is like this, without not being in danger. For this reason, I became a monk.
'Smearing a sharp knife with honey, a child greedy for sweetness licks it with its tongue, and there is the danger of having its tongue cut off.
A lustful person, just to satisfy his foolish mind, does not consider that later there will be the harm of burning the body.'
It is like a starving dog finding a bone on the road, gnawing and biting it, injuring its mouth and breaking its teeth, only harming itself, of what benefit is it to itself?
Lust and debauchery are like this, for hundreds of thousands of koá¹­is of kalpas there is no merit as small as a hair, but there are the offenses of the three evil paths.
I think of this, therefore I became a Å›ramaá¹‡a.

It is like a tree with luxuriant flowers and fruits, passersby covet them, beating and picking them with sticks and stones, in an instant the flowers are damaged and the fruits fall, the branches and leaves are injured.
The tree, with its flowers and fruits, invites its own destruction;
Moths covet the color of fire, fly into the lamp, and burn their bodies, what do they gain in the end?

Those who are confused by lust do not distinguish good from evil, distance the wise and befriend the foolish, day by day they fall into darkness, lose their country and destroy their people, die and enter hell, evil leads to the completion of offenses, what regret will they have?
The Buddha sees this clearly and reveals the noble path.
By the Buddha's grace, I have been able to see the sutras and precepts. My mind guards purity and I am alone without worries. Looking back at the worldly currents, I realize it was a mistake.
For this reason, I have become a monk.
When Seng Da heard this, he bowed at his feet and knelt for a long time, saying:
The Buddha is the true supreme sage, revered by all gods!
The sutras eliminate delusion and enter my heart.
I wish to leave the turbidity of the world and tread the path of purity. I will uphold the precepts of a monk as my glorious blessings.
The master then instructed him on the grave precepts of a monk.
After serving the master for several months, he said to the master:
Why do you wish to enter the mountains, peacefully concentrate and meditate, seek the path of an arhat, and thereby end suffering?
The master said:
Living alone in the mountains is a great difficulty.
Those who dwell in the wilds should study the stars and know the times. They should always store water, fire, and honey.

The reason is that when thieves seek water, fire, flour, or honey in the middle of the night or towards dawn, they must be understood and given what they desire. If their wishes are not met, the thieves will kill people.ğŸ”½ The monk said:
Yes!
I respectfully follow your kind teachings and will learn what you have instructed.
Then he entered the mountains.
His brother thought:
My younger brother has become a monk and will never keep a wife.
The wife Kaisaeng was unparalleled in her beauty. The brother was delighted with her and rose to follow Kaisaeng, holding a qin and playing it himself, singing a song of lust:
The brilliant turmeric grows in the wild fields, but if not harvested in time, it is seen as abandoned.
Luxuriant and flourishing, the flower's color is only new. To share joy with me is a deep intimacy. In a year, who will value it again?
Kaisaeng immediately realized that her brother wanted to cause chaos and replied to Buddha-da with a song:
My teacher is lofty, revered by gods and humans, his disciples are pure, and they are called Å›ramaá¹‡as.
Praising truth is considered sage, while lust is likened to the animal realm.
I have received strict precepts, not serving two masters, I will never engage in lustful relations, rather I would rather die.
The Buddha then sang a song of great compassion and lament, with mournful words:
My heart has been set on you for a long time, so I used a good matchmaker, inquired about your name, visited your teacher, and chose an auspicious time;
Anxious and fearful, worried you wouldn't come, but seeing your radiant countenance, my heart is overjoyed;
If we do not unite now, it would be a waste.
This vow is set in stone, virtuous woman, what doubts do you have?
Subhadra was frightened and sang a reply:
The Buddha establishes rituals, with distinctions between superiors and inferiors, a younger wife is like a son, a husband's elder brother is like a father.
I personally uphold the precepts, with daily advancement, truly equal to the sages, lust is like an animal.
Alas, elder brother!
How can I believe such words?
The elder brother's mind was confused, greedy for the good and beautiful sight, his intention was even more intense, and he could not be turned away.
KuÅ›in then sang again:
When a person is in the world, they should stay away from two things:
Disobedience and licentiousness.
If one's actions violate the Buddha's precepts, the gods and sages will record their differences.
The Buddha sang a great song:
Your appearance is so radiant and bright, is there any woman in the world with a face like yours? My mind is delighted, so I cross the great mountain.
KuÅ›in thought to herself:
This son desires me, his madness is chaotic, and he brings great difficulty.
I will ask to speak about the impurities of the body, and then he will leave.
KuÅ›in said again:
You are greedy for my body, but what is good about it?
The head has nine bones, which form the skull, inside there is only brain, the face has seven orifices, all of which produce mucus and saliva;
The skin covers the bones, those who crave the head and neck, the skin and flesh cover each other, the body has hair, nails, teeth, skin, muscles, blood, brain, bones, and flesh;
In the abdomen there is the heart, spleen, kidneys, intestines, stomach, fat, lungs, feces, pus, blood, cold and heat;

The feet are connected to the shins, the shins are connected to the thighs, the thighs are connected to the hips, the hips are connected to the waist, the waist is connected to the spine, the spine is connected to the ribs, the ribs are connected to the neck, the neck is connected to the skull, the arms are connected to the elbows, the elbows are connected to the shoulders.
I am like a painted vase, filled with feces inside, the impurities in the body are so disgusting, how can one crave it?
Whatever people like, if one speaks of its evil, the mind will immediately despise it.
The Buddha thought to himself:
If she thinks of her husband, how would she listen to me?
Only if I kill my brother will she follow me.
The Buddha became very angry and went out to recruit a few thieves.
Seeing a light and thin person in a wine shop, he went up to him and said:
Do you know that the son of a slave I keep at home has escaped and become a monk, now in the mountains?
The thief said:
I know him.
Buddhadatta then took out gold and silver to give to him, ordering him to kill the slave's son:
Quickly take his head, the clothes on his body, the Dharma staff he carries, and the shoes on his feet, and return them all to me. I will give you more gold and silver.
The thief was overjoyed and said:
Follow me to get them.
He then went into the mountains.
Arriving at his brother's place, he called out:
Monk!
You should come out quickly.
His brother came out and said:
What do you gentlemen seek?
I have water, fire, flour, and honey to eat.
It was already past midnight, and the thief said:
I do not seek water, fire, salt, or honey, nor do I ask about your time. I only wish to take your head and go.
When his younger brother heard this, he was greatly frightened and wept, saying:
I am not the son of a wealthy lord!

I left the secular world to pursue the Way, and have no disputes with the world. My study of the Way is still shallow, and I have not yet attained the six spiritual powers of the stream-enterer, once-returner, non-returner, or arhat. What benefit is there in killing me?
The bandit said:
I came to take your head. What benefit is there in begging for mercy?
His younger brother thought to himself:
This bandit has only heard that my family is wealthy and thinks I have brought treasures here.
He said to the bandit:
If you want treasures, my elder brother at home is called Buddhadatta. I will write to him to give you treasures. You can get whatever you desire, according to your wishes.
The bandit said:
Your elder brother ordered me to come and kill you.
His younger brother said:
I will die now, because of this woman.
The master previously warned me:
Living with a lustful person is like carrying a torch against the wind - if you do not let go of it early, the fire will burn your hand;
It is like a knife smeared with honey, like a hawk chasing a crow, a dog getting a dry bone, a tree with flowers and fruit.
The harm to the body caused by desire is as deep as the master's warning.
He wept and followed the thief, saying:
Please give me one year to live, so that I can attain the Way.
I will always be here, it is not too late to kill me.
The thief said:
Now I want to take your head, how can you say one year?
Many mountain-dwelling practitioners attain the Way, I'm afraid you will lightly display your spiritual powers and leave.
Don't say much more, capture and take your head.
His younger brother said again:
Please don't kill me immediately, first cut off one of my thighs and place it in front of me.
The thief then went forward and first cut off one of his thighs and placed it in front of him.
His younger brother suffered from this pain, the pain was indescribable, the heavenly being came down to where the practitioner was and said:
Be careful not to be afraid, firmly hold your mind.
In your past lives, you entered the animal realm, and people slaughtered and sold your flesh, not just for one lifetime.
You have experienced suffering in the hells and as hungry ghosts, the pain has not just begun now.
Sengda said to the heavenly being:
Please have pity on me and tell my teacher to know - because of the teacher, I was shown the Way - where is there death and life?
The heavenly being then went to tell his teacher:
Your virtuous disciple, whom people are about to kill, is weeping and begging for mercy, wanting to see the teacher.
The teacher flew to where his disciple was and spoke a sutra for him, saying:
Heaven and earth, Mount Sumeru, still have destruction, the ocean has exhaustion, and the seven suns have destruction.
There is a wind in the world called VÄ«raá¹‡a. When VÄ«raá¹‡a arises, mountains collide with mountains. This wind will cease, let alone your small body, what comparison is there?
You should only think of the Buddha.

The Buddha always says that what is impermanent will end, what is prosperous will decline, what comes together will separate, and glorious positions are difficult to maintain, the body is also like this.
Sengda then attained the path of stream-entry;
He further cut off a thigh, again contemplated the teacher's precepts, and further attained the path of once-returning;
The thief cut off his left arm, again contemplated the teacher's precepts, and attained the path of non-returning;
The thief cut off his right arm, again contemplated the teacher's precepts, and attained the path of arhatship;
He then had no fear of the three evil paths, was free in birth and death, and had nothing more to fear.
Sengda said:
Take some tree bark.
He then peeled off some tree bark and gave it to him.
Sengda took a branch as a pen, pierced his own blood, and wrote on the tree bark:
Elder brother!
Are you well in your daily activities?
When my parents were alive, I relied on my elder brother.
My elder brother did not follow their instructions, disobeying his parents' teachings, and killing each other because of women.
Disobeying my parents' kind teachings is unfilial;
Killing human life is unrighteous.
The sin of killing one animal is not small, let alone killing an arhat.
I did not stop it, but my elder brother brought it upon himself.
Think of me, with a body, who can be killed;
The Well-Gone One is tranquil, yet you still harm each other.
Part ways, be diligent, and aspire to the true path.
Pulling his neck two feet long, he said to the thief:
You cut off my head, because of the mud on my head, do not be afraid.
I fear that you will fall into hell.

The thief cut off his head in front of them, took his upper robe, staff, sandals, and alms bowl, and brought them to his brother. The robe, staff, sandals, and bowl were all given to the brother, who heavily thanked the thief with gold and silver.
The brother took his brother's head, made a fake body, put the head on top, covered it with a robe, and placed the staff, bowl, and sandals beside it. He said to BhadrÄ:
Your husband has returned, you can greet him.
BhadrÄ was overjoyed and ran to his side. Seeing him sitting with his eyes closed, she thought he was contemplating the Way, and the wife did not dare call out to him.
She prepared delicious food and waited, thinking:
When he wakes up, I will feed him.
At noon he did not wake up. The wife then said:
It is now noon, I'm afraid it will be past the time.
She wondered why he did not respond. She pulled on his robe and lifted him up. The head fell to the ground and the body all scattered, each on one side.
The wife was then greatly frightened and wailed:
You have sat here long enough, I see the remaining bandits!
Grieving and enraged, he called out to heaven, his liver and heart torn apart, blood gushing from his mouth, and he suddenly died.
His precepts and conduct were pure and untainted, like the sky; his mind was set on the holy model, unshakable like the earth; his upright and pure conduct was lofty, unfathomable like heaven.
When he was about to die, the gods praised him and peacefully arranged his rebirth, welcoming his spirit to dwell in the Heaven of the Thirty-three.
Enduring a moment of lust, he obtained the glory of heaven that is difficult to exhaust.

The elder brother entered the spirit chamber to see what his wife was doing. The elder brother saw his younger brother's head and body scattered and dismembered, and his wife vomiting blood and dead on one side.
The elder brother saw his younger brother's corpse dead like this and called out:
Alas, alas!
I have acted against heaven and done something cruel, leading to this.
The elder brother then went to the bandits and asked their intentions:
Did my younger brother have any last words when he was about to die?ğŸ”½The bandits said:
Yes, he did.
There is a letter.
He took out the letter and showed it to the king.
After reading the letter, the king was choked with grief and tears flowed uncontrollably:
I disobeyed my parents' instructions when they were still alive, causing the destruction of my relatives, and I even killed an arhat. I died in a fit of rage, and after death, I entered hell.
When the king and his ministers heard this news, they wept and choked with sobs. They praised his pure virtues and buried his younger brother.
The four groups erected a stupa, and devas, nÄgas, and spirits filled the sky, scattering flowers and burning incense, all moved to the heart.

His wife, KÄntimati, was buried by the people of the country. The mourning moved the whole country, and the people praised her for attaining the Way through diligence, not violating the five precepts, and being reborn in the heavens.
Disobeying the Buddha's teachings, being unfilial, and harming the sages, one will die and enter hell, to be burned and boiled in suffering for countless years.
The Buddha then told his disciples, From now on, you should admonish each other to be free from desires.
After the Buddha finished speaking the sÅ«tra, the disciples joyfully made obeisance and departed.
